newsitem.title: UK: CRICKET-GRAVENEY NAMED AS CHAIRMAN OF SELECTORS.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-GRAVENEY NAMED AS CHAIRMAN OF SELECTORS.

text.p: Former Gloucestershire and Durham captain David Graveney was named as England's new chairman of selectors on Thursday and said he was cautiously optimistic about the side's future prospects.
"We haven't had too much success in the last four or five years but we can certainly build on the results we've had in New Zealand and on those back-to-back test victories," he said.
Graveney replaces Ray Illingworth, who retired at the end of the last English season.
His appointment on a two-year contract was confirmed at a news conference at Lord's during which former England captains Graham Gooch and Mike Gatting were named as selectors.
Essex opening batsman Gooch has been given a two-year contract while Gatting has been taken on for a year.

Graveney originally challenged Illingworth for the high-profile post of chairman of selectors a year ago but had to withdraw when the English Professional Cricketers' Association, of which he is general secretary, complained of a conflict of interests.
The chairman's role has been modified since then to allow Graveney to combine both posts.

"It's been redefined but I don't think it's less important than it was," he said. "You can't have anything much more important than selecting the 11 or 12 or 13 people who are going to play for your country. I just think it's a little bit more discrete and doesn't overflow into the management function."
Graveney would not be drawn on whether Mike Atherton would retain his post as England captain.
"Graham Gooch and Mike Gatting and I have got to sit down and talk to Mike," he said. "It would be very wrong for me to cast my opinion in public without consulting the other two."
